Description: Solid-cast amuletic figure of the god Harpokrates in copper alloy; god represented as naked male child, slightly bent or seated, his arms by his sides, wearing an elaborate feathered headdress (Hemhem crown) and the sidelock of youth to the right side of his head; very simplistic and flat rendering; slightly corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Bronze figures of Harpokrates were common during the Late and Ptolemaic periods in Egypt (Weiss 2012, 126-157, Typ 41-69, Pl. 11-19), chiefly in the Delta where his cult was particularly developed (Sandri 2006). Likewise, the child deity was very popular in Naukratis. He appears in a large number of small votives and amuletic figures, in a variety of materials and shapes (Masson forthcoming). This figure of Harpokrates belongs to the type 59 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss, a relatively rare type found also in Bubastis, Athribis and Saqqara (Weiss 2012, 147, 606-607, Pl. 17c-e). The very flat and crude design featured on this figure is found on other Naukratite bronzes, such as: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.247, 86.251, 86.253, 86.261 and 86.284; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.616; BM 1885,1101.568 and BM 1885,1101.91.
